>>53125274
That's a good idea, but you also need to be submitting stuff in the right s14 cell. If that gym across from him is in the same cell, then he's going to need to get at least four more stops up. Read this:

https://pokemongohub.net/post/article/comprehensive-guide-s2-cells-pokemon-go/#:~:text=Pok%C3%A9mon%20GO%20is%20built%20on%20top%20of%20S2,translate%20Earth%E2%80%99s%20spherical%203D%20shape%20into%202D%20geometry.

Then use:

https://www.pogomap.info/

To check where the cells line up in your are, you can go into settings on the map and choose either level 17 or 14 cells. Also, using the Ingress Intel Map can be useful as well as it shows all POIs, even ones that didn't make it into Go.

You’re walking in the woods with your rucksack. You aren’t the most experienced with packing your ruck, so it’s always so big on you. It’s 11 in the morning, beams of sunlight piercing the rooftop of the forest in small patches, here and there. After a bit of walking, you fight through foliage to see a girl sitting on a boulder. She’s wearing a black dress, has short black hair with a cowlick in the back, in her hair is a white bow. She notices you and greets herself. “I’m Marley. What brings you out here?” You can tell she’s kind of reserved and shy. You inform her that you’re just on a walk. “Really? You must know the way out of this forest. Can I join you?” You tell her “Yes” after a moment of contemplating. It seems kind of suspicious traveling with a girl who looks like she’s still in high school, but her companionship wouldn’t be too bad, especially since you often get lonely in your strolls. Time passes by, and she seems to have warmed up to you after some casual chitchat. “If I’m gonna be honest Anon, I don’t like talking. I can’t figure out what to say to people fast enough, so they just look at me with disgust and confusion. But I can talk to you normally, because you seem to understand me.” As you look at Marley, she looks away, blushing with a cute smile. She has feelings for you, but she’s far too nervous to let them known. After some walking, you both decide to sit under a tree to eat. You pull out goods from your rucksack, getting a can of beefaroni for yourself and giving a PBJ sandwich to Marley. After eating, you pack the trash away in your ruck. Marley is slightly appalled by your inability to effectively pack it tight. “Make it smaller Anon.” She lets out a small but cute chuckle as you begin to wrap around your ruck in a fetal position, humping it in a desperate yet pathetic attempt to make it smaller.
1/2

>>53104513
It's been suggested to me.

The issue for me is that I'm a stream of consciousness kind of writer. I don't "do" outlines and try to avoid knowing anything about what happens between the first and last line. (I try to find the ending before getting beyond a first or second chapter as applicable, but I don't want any idea of how I'll get there.) Taking a commission is the opposite. What will be "in" it will be prescribed and there are expectations of content. I want to write against expectations and with only the framing context having been predetermined.

I'd probably do much better on a patronage model than a contractor basis. Presuming I get back on the grind, someday.

posts.com:
Looking at the constant stream of journeyfics being posted on FFN got me thinking: is it rare for people to do a journeyfic in their homebrew region? It seems a lot more rare than I thought.

I've always had the idea for a journeyfic (as a Pokemon writer, who hasn't?), but I never really seemed to into the idea of using a canon region. Canon characters (gym leaders), yes. I this common with other Pokemon writers?

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53105573
I've gone somewhat the other way around.

Although the very first pokemon fic idea I had was in Johto by default, as I was playing HGSS at the time, once I decided to write it out and that some of my pokemon could talk (necessitating a conceit to sell it) I recast it as a homebrew region. It remains somewhat Johto like in broad strokes, and I pulled a bit of a stunt to keep them connected (that there is another archaeological site there claiming to also be the Ruins of Alph, implying a connection which I've left lying there for a decade…), but quickly became its own thing and gave me a lot of blank canvas to work with.

But now I've somewhat returned to it with my current WIP, which follows a canon-region trainer who is going to visit said Ruins, have an experience, and wind up on her way to my region.

As for why, I think that likely most writers want to self-insert and it's much easier to work in the Pokemon World by using places that are there. A homebrew region requires drawing a map to keep it straight.

>Canon characters (gym leaders), yes.
Those would be somewhat bound to canon regions, unless a bunch are visiting the homebrew land for… a convention I guess? See, it takes some doing.

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53114015
Use what sounds best, foremost. But, if the Mirelands are a bunch of locations, prefer the plural. If it's really one spot, prefer the singular.

In my experience, collective plurals are different in US and UK English, with US favoring the collective as a unit versus UK favouring the collective as a collection. I.e., "Our team is leading in sales," in the US, versus "Our team are leading in sales" in UK. Works on bands and soccer clubs.

Yeah, you absolutely don’t need to do porn, but you need to be hitting some sort of niche/fandom. On RoyalRoad the biggest cash cows seem to be LitRPGs. Levels, stats, the whole enchilada. Doesn’t have to be isekai, but it helps. It’s not really fanfiction and the market’s somewhat saturated, but RR isn’t really a fanfic site to begin with, and hey, it’s what the people demand. I see a lot of authors setting up Patreons and giving of advanced chapters as rewards, so maybe that’d work for you.

On AO3/Wattpad/everything else the big thing seems to be fandoms. Make a really popular story about a popular anime/video game and link your Ko Fi or whatever. At least a couple people will bite, but really it depends on your popularity levels.

On the whole, there’s definitely money to be made. People are a lot more eager to spend money online than they were not that long ago, and it’s baffling to me. Instead of saving up to go to Barnes and Noble and buy a couple books, Zoomers today are probably timing Patreon payments and setting apart commission money to give to internet people.

>>53124717
There's a debate over whether Amazon publishing is self publishing and I'd call it like the 2.5D of publishing. Which, that being said it should be pretty clear that Amazon is my answer to your question. Publishing through established print publisher is becoming increasingly ridiculous, which is making self/Amazon publishing increasingly viable. You get to keep 60% of the profit which is a very fair slice for the industry, and especially worthwhile when you consider how unfathomably massive Amazon's userbase is; unless you have tons of connections, your work is not gonna find nearly the level of reach through traditional publishing as it can on Amazon. I would absolutely recommend that anyone who enjoys writing and wants to try publishing should give it a try, it's free on Amazon so it's not like it'll hurt you to fail besides pride reasons. My best advice is to find a niche; for example, children's action adventures like I write are a very specific niche, whereas something like horror or scifi is gonna be up against an endless sea of competitors. I've heard that ultimately, people who write recipe books, music books, wilderness guides, etc. that kind of stuff on Amazon have the most success, but ultimately if you're autistic enough to also be posting alongside me on a Pokemon 4chan board, I'm gonna assume that you've also got niche enough tastes for it to be worth a try. Always follow your dreams anon, failing at something you've always wanted to do is 100000x better than spending a lifetime wondering how you would've done.

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53129434
Self insert is when someone daydreams about being a hero and then writes it as a story.

It's not truly a bad thing in itself. Tom Clancy did well with his self-insert stories of being a special agent. However, it provides much opportunity to write things that make for lame storytelling. Because self-insert is writing for one's ego, it's very easy for said ego to make storytelling decisions that are about aggrandizing the self rather than challenging the self and demonstrating an interesting way that the author can find to solve the problem.

Naturally, amateurs can easily stumble into these tropes by accident as well as by inexperience when not deliberate ego stroking. This leads to the trope of the "Mary Sue," a self-insert character who is given so many talents, skills, benefits, lucky breaks, and inexplicable advantages that there are no challenges that aren't overcome by author simply explaining them away rather than portraying a two-sided, believable conflict. This quickly burns suspension of disbelief and turns the work into a laughing stock.

>why is it so popular
It can be an escapism for the author, or a form of self expression. But I don't believe self-insert (done poorly) is popular; supply outweighs demand.

>a character who is suitably generic that the reader can pretend it's themself?
Oneself.
Generic protagonist needn't be self-insert, just bland. But that can be the intention with second-person perspective pieces. (Which are very difficult to write well and I'm not sure that I've ever seen a fan fic pull it off.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53129434
No, I believe a so-called "self-insert" fic is the author's SI specifically. There is a whole 'nother genre - often smut or at least romance - that is written in the second person without identifying much about the reader (generally if e.g. a particular genital configuration is required for things to progress as they will, the work will be tagged as such on AO3).
This is also smelly and I do not condone it. But at least its overly indulgent raison d'être is plain to see; that is, even if I don't like it, I get why they're there and why they're popular. Simple fandom trappings we're unlikely to escape in our lifetimes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53132534
SI gets hate because inserting yourself as the main character can lead to a power fantasy, cringe, or often a blend of both. Given that this is fanfiction and the majority of writers are far from pros, a lot of SI authors tend to try and boost the likeability of their protagonist (themselves) by making them extra special: mastery of aura that makes a pack of Lucario jealous, the attractiveness of Adonis, born an unstoppable battle genius, etc.

In the worst cases you have authors completely butcher existing characters for the sake of elevating their SI, either in error or sometimes deliberate if they happen to despise the character in question. Everything, from existing characters to the plot itself, is thrown on the sacrificial pyre for the benefit of Tyson, 25 year-old turned ten-year old master psychic, aura-user, and lady pleaser.

Now OC protags can end up the same of course and sometimes readers like a bit of powerwank (I find Borne of Caution to still be a decent read despite it for example), but a lot of SI's go overboard with it to an intolerable degree. At this point there's so many SI's that fuck it up and add shit like random magical katanas to make the protag 'cool', seeing 'self-insert' is just a red flag for a lot of readers.

You know Sturgeon's Law? "90% of everything is crap?" That applies double to anything involving the written word, because what makes good writing is less immediately apparent obvious than what makes good music or art, and so many more people believe they can write well than who actually can. It also applies triple to any fanwork because communities don't gatekeep like we used to and it's 'rude' and 'confrontational' to kick out somebody who's dumping toxic sludge into the community watering hole.
Cherish the good ones, lads, and even the just pretty-alright ones. Because they're hardly a dime a dozen in spaces like these.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Legends battle system was perfect. The camera movement and character animations was smooth and to the point, it didn't hang for a few seconds like in SV. The menus felt snappy and responsive unlike SV, and I loved how menu options were assigned to buttons. It's a crime that they went back to the fucking GameBoy menu in SV. The move animations were actually pretty good, and for the first time in the mainline games the Pokémon actually move around and make physical contact. I loved how time sometimes slowed down on the impact when you made super-effective hits and the camera shook a bit, it made battles feel a bit more action-packed. The battles in SV are fucking boring and look like shit. I also hate how zoomed in the battle camera is in SV.

There's also other stuff that Legends did that makes it so great, but I'm not gonna go into any of that. I'll just end it saying PLA was miles better than SV and anyone saying otherwise is a shill or a mindless NPC who doesn't want Pokémon to improve.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53108786
I think this game was just alright, a lot of promise a lot of ass, a lot of soul a lot of slog. I think anyone who finds it the best or worst game is most likely lying to themself out of autistic passion, but ultimately it falls on the better half of the series. I think its mechanical contributions are pretty great, but that its new pokedex and characters are ugly and kinda suck, and while the former criteria will get me to finish a game, the latter criteria really kills its chances of being top tier for me. I can’t say “Oh yeah it’s a perfect take on Pokemon, but all of the new Pokemon are unsightly hideous and the characters are boring fugly fan service” idk about y’all but a game can’t be one of the best with that holding it back. I didn’t mind the crafting or the tasks nearly as much as the autists on this board led me to believe I would, but even then a Pokemon game where the new Pokemon and Pokemon Trainers suck is not a Pokemon game that can ever be higher than middle of the road, I’m sorry bros.

Happy birthday Legends Arceus, you’re not the perfect game, but you were the most fun GF has given us in years, they failed you in terms of your new content and post-launch support, you deserved better. To honor its successes, I shall post one of the three good new Pokemon it gave us.

Also (same anon warning you about the troll) idk why you guys think GF sabotaged their own revenue machine, the real answer is way simpler and way stupider than that.

Legends underperformed because it was a single version with no legendary on the cover art. If they released it as Legends Dialga and Legends Palkia with the new forms on the cover, it would’ve sold as much as series standards for new games. Ultimately, going for a single title really fucked them over, and including a Pokemon’s name in the title but not on the box art was a weird decision that no doubt alienated a lot of potential buyers, hell those simple design choices have autistic man children on this board TO THIS DAY who don’t think it’s a main series game, imagine what it did to casual consumers (or their parents). I’m expecting the Legends series will continue, but that the next entry will have two versions and legendaries on the cover, screencap this, I am the most reliable GF analyst in board history, trust me here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53126413

It got DLC anon. You didn’t notice because the DLC was a free download. PLA was truly the best single player Pokémon game experience.

To this day, PLA is the ONLY mainline game where all available Pokémon can be caught on a single trainer ID. I remember starting another save, thinking I would transfer starters once Home was available, but then I realized I could get them in my first save. Thought the same thing about the odds of finding fossil mons and STD mons, but no, I was able to find them all too.

It is also the best game for shiny hunting. The charm is basically impossible to get on multiple saves for the average person, but it is totally worth it. The sound and star visual make sense lore wise because your character has been studying Pokémon in the wild in great detail. From a lore perspective, you would naturally recognize more shiny Pokémon after studying them intensely to fill out all the dex entries.

Oh, and to top it all off, the cinematic cut scenes were all on point.

posts.com:
I needed to try something and I've been wanting to try out a rocket-locke for a while, so I may start out a run next weekend if I finish Dead Space 2 by then.

The basics is that I can steal any pokemon from the trainer I battle first in an area (really interesting because if you can avoid trainers you have some control over the potential pools depending on trainer types). Also, to compensate for missing catches due to some areas having no trainers, I will allow myself to try capturing each gym's leader last pokemon.

But I need help deciding how to implement a dupes clause. I'm thinking that it only comes into play when the trainer I choose happens to only be carrying one single mon I already have. Because otherwise, if I'm against a trainer with 3 mons for example, and I skip the first 2 to fish for something better only to get a dupe, it just doesn't feel fair that I get to retry with another trainer: I chose to risk it and I should face the consequences.

Thoughts?

>>53133228
The music is still good, I still find some locales charming, I like the gen 2 dex (hope you do too because that's like, 60% of the availible mons), mirror B is the best meme this franchise has ever birthed and I like 2v2 when it actually feels like 2v2.
2v2 is pretty uninteresting to me when it's pretty much just 1v1 but with more mons.
IE : most of my playthroughs both as a kid and later as an adult would just be the same STAB spam fest as mainline games but with the added caviat that i could focus one mon or the other at the price of every turn being four times slower and maybe that one fight where a minor boss spams EQ+levitate.
The "difficulty" romhacks Grand colosseum and next gen are worth trying IMO since they "fix" the game by giving you and the CPUs interesting 2v2 toys, weather settling, spread moves, intimidaters and so on while being leagues from the bullshit level of difficulty of things like kaizo.

Tera Band Crunch 2HKOs at worst everything in the tier including resists, so absolutely nothing but certain scarfers, priority users or strategic Terastal mons can check it.
Tera Blast Electric beats all of its "checks" if you run HDB.
It's not that squishy either, 80/80 physical bulk is respectable.
Its defensive type is not that useless, it has key resistances that can be exploited.
Pao is a premier wallbreaker, revenge killer and sweeper all rolled into one. No other offensive mon in the tier can compress all offensive roles in a single set and excel at all of them at once.
Chi-Yu is a nuke, but 100 base speed means it either wallbreaks or runs scarf and Overheat can't be spammed as much as Pao's STABs, plus it has no priority.

posts.com:
Bored out of my mind and it wandred to comp, so I'm gonn type out some changes I'd make to the past 3 generational gimmicks if they're ever to return in an official capacity
>Megas
The stats gained now scale with the initial BST of the mon. For example, if a mon had less than, say, 500 BST, they'd get the full 100 BST boost, but if they had 600 BST, they'd get a heavily reduced BST bump of only around 10. This forces the already "strong" Pokemon getting Megas to take those optimal stats from an actual place they'd miss then rather than becoming nonsensical statblobs. If Mega Metgross still want its' 145 attack, 105 special attack, and 110 speed, it'll have to eat into it's HP, Defense, and Special Defense to do so even with the points afforded to it, whereas Megas like Audino and Sableye won't have to suffer. This also further pushes the "Megas as an alternative rather than straight updgrade" angle Kalosfags desperately want you to believe applied for more than a small handful of them.
>Z-Moves
When a Pokemon holding a Z-Crystal swaps in, the type of cystal it's holding is announced. For example, you swap Heatran holding a Grassium-Z in and the text "Heatran is a giving off an intensely verdant aura!" shows with an accompanying visual.
>Dynamax
Max HP bonus goes from 2x to 1.5x, ALL stat boosting Max Moves are capped to 100 BP in the BEST case, and Gmaxes are now given the option to use their Gmax moves alongside normal Max Moves. After they Gmax, another prompt like the initial DMax one shows up with a new symbol. Selecting it will allow you to hen use the Gmax move for the corresponding type of move that turn However, you can only do this ONCE. This change is gonna require a mass rebalancing of G-Max moves overall (the Kanto trio's moves literally only need to be used once to get max value in their current state, so cut their duration down to 4 turns, for example), but I think it'd be overall healthier.
Thoughts?

>>53123758
The only type weak to both Fire and Ice is Grass. It'd still be weak to Flying, Bug, and Poison in that case. You could use it to add resistances to an already decent defensive type, but most defensive Teras are into Steel or Water, and they both resist Ice while Water also resists Fire.

Turning it into a Flying type could be a decent idea. It'd only be weak to Electric and Rock, it'd resist Fighting, Bug, Grass, and Fire, and it'd be immune to Ground. Steel resists/is immune to all the types that are SE against Appletun, so that's an obvious choice, but it makes the Ice resist from Thick Fat rather redundant. You could honestly make good use of a Ripen set with one of the boost berries to get a +2 stat boost if it were Steel type.

posts.name: Anonymous

Appletun makes do with Leech Seed. It's just not that threatening of a Pokemon with base 100 SpA. It could use +10 to Def, SpD, and SpA. Band needs icicle spinner/crash + crunch + sacred sword or else it doesn't work as well. Ice moves are needed for pokemon like great tusk, dragonite, and all the tera faries out there. Psychic fangs won't ohko great tusk and tera fairy skeledirge (if defensive) for example will be impossible to beat without your ice moves. Sacred sword is needed for Kingambit and most importantly opposing Chien Paos. Then you've got that last slot which you can give to psychic fangs but then you lose priority moves which means you lose to things like dragapult and boosted valiant. You can definitely run it if you really want to lure Tauros but there's a big cost to that

I went all the way back to Dewford on my Tropius to grab the Old Rod and catch a Magikarp. Although Wynaut knows Splash I didn't want to risk it surviving one of their psychic attacks in the red, which can happen with one of their Gym Trainers. I know this because I tried to just get it over with using Wynaut, then it survived against a Gym Trainer, which made me reset.

Anyway, Tate and Liza did actually require me to use my brain to win. Bulk Up and Fighting Attacks weren't going to cut it because they do way too much damage right off the bat. For those who may have forgotten, the twins lead with Xatu and Claydol, so you're either going to get hit with a psychic-or-ground-type attack. I replaced Blaziken's Sky Uppercut with Overheat, which one-shot Claydol. This makes Tate send out Solrock, which will pretty reliably (I say this because it did it twice) use Sunny Day right after it comes out. I used the Sunny Day boosted Overheat to one-shot Xatu. Then I Double Kicked Lunatone and Solrock for the win. It actually did take me a few tries. I was able to do it without relying on items though.

>>53127492
At least, in the case of Emerald version, “over-leveled starter” posting is incorrect both practically and philosophically.

Blaziken beating Wallace basically just comes down to the player getting lucky. I used Overheat, Rock Tomb, Double Kick, and Bulk Up on mine. I had to run Rock Tomb to get past Drake’s Salamence. One-shotting Wallace’s Pokémon was absolutely mandatory, because if I didn’t, they would one-shot me, unless I got very lucky and they didn’t use a STAB move like Surf or in Whiscash’s case, Earthquake. To do that, I needed to use Bulk Up twice, and to do that, I needed to lower Wailord’s HP so that Water Spout only did about 50 damage each time. Setting up on anyone but Wailord is not viable, because everyone has Surf except for Tentacruel, who has Hydro Pump. Two Bulk Ups lets Blaziken reliably one-shot Wailord, Ludicolo, Whiscash and Milotic with Double Kick. After Milotic it’s ALL luck. As soon as Tentacruel comes out, it’s a matter of will Hydro Pump miss? And for that matter, will any of my moves Crit? Because Gyarados has Intimidate, one of your Bulk Ups doesn’t count, meaning you need to crit with Rock Tomb or Gyarados will survive with red HP, and then one-shot you. (1/3)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53130820
Maybe it gets better with the liberal use of X-Items and items-in-battle, but I tried to avoid doing that as much as possible because I was trying to see how “easy” the game was. Which brings me to my next point: how easy is Pokémon REALLY? Maybe some ideal set-up exists for Blaziken that makes creaming the Elite Four and Champion a breeze. Maybe if I learned Slash or deleted Peck for Overheat instead of Sky Uppercut, I’d have had an easier time. Maybe if I got a specific item, or grabbed a TM, it would have been easier. Maybe I missed a few trainers at sea or in a cave or off the beaten path somewhere. I definitely didn’t do every double battle. Maybe the extra levels would have helped. But does it really matter? If I needed to do that stuff, if I had to go out of my way to prepare by hunt down specific items, how easy was the challenge? If I had to heal, or pop an X-Item, how easy was the challenge? I still had to use my head to win. I had to read, contextualize, and think.

Phoebe would have been much easier with any other Pokémon, to shake Curse. Drake would have been much easier with a Rock-type, or an Electric-type, and Wallace would have been a lot easier with a Grass-type on my team. I caught a Tropius. I deleted its Razor Leaf since I wasn’t going to fight with it anyway, but that’s just one example of a Pokémon that would have been a big help. I could have caught an Oddish, Roselia, Shroomish, or even an Electrike, and given it the EXP. Share, and not had this problem. It would have been much less demanding to just switch out. If I had something to switch out to. So there actually is a practical incentive to use more than one Pokémon: type coverage. The player learns this as soon as they learn different Pokémon have different types. I was more than 10 levels higher than Wallace’s strongest Pokémon and it didn’t matter. He was still one-shotting me. (2/3)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53130824
Another thing I didn’t want to do was fight the same Trainer twice. So, if I lost after knocking out one of their Pokémon, I just reset and fought them again from the beginning. I did this to avoid getting experience, and I found it to be especially relevant with the Elite Four. Losing to any of them means having to start the gauntlet over, which means you could hypothetically accrue lots of experience and just keep leveling up until you’re so strong they’re not one-shotting you. In what world does that mean the game is easy? You lost a bunch of times before getting that win. How do you lose to somebody a bunch of times, finally beat them, and then say beating them was easy? If it was easy, why did you take so long to do it?

I didn’t even get into whether small children would be inclined to use strategies revolving around moves like Bulk Up which see a delayed return on investment, over just spamming attacks, which provide instant gratification. Maybe they would. After losing a bunch. But that’s a point in Pokémon’s favor, because it teaches children to THINK.

On that note, starter-only runs are challenge runs. They just are. Using one Pokémon, no matter which it is severely limits the ways you can interact with your opponent’s type, forcing you to think about how you can maximize the profits of interacting with YOUR type. In other words, STAB. It also forces you to think about Pokémon stats. Type interaction is at the heart of battling in these games, and I would say that not interacting with anyone’s type at all is the only way to play Pokémon “incorrectly”, which brings me to my last point.

Although you have every incentive not to, the fact you can do something close to a starter-only run is actually really good game design. (3/3)

Steel was offensively saved (used to be the second worst attacking type after poison), but losing dark and ghost resists made those types a bit too strong offensively. I think steel needed another weakness (like electric which makes sense) more than less resists.
Dragon should have been resisted by Ice, which is a type that already had issues but the introduction of Fairy made them worse.
Bug was gutted, everyone agrees on that.
At least Ice is excellent offensively and ice types have access to exclusive moves like Freeze-Dry and Aurora Veil water types don't get.
The best thing about Bug as a type are U-turn and Quiver Dance which are not exclusive to Bug mons.
Fire got a Fairy resistance only because they had to shill Mega Blaziken (only gen 3 starter that originally got a Mega) and Charizard (only mon besides Mewtwo that got two).

Let's not even get started on the design direction of Fairy type pokemon, being randomly slapped on things that look cute/pink/feminine.

That's about two-thirds where I went with pokeballs in my stories.

There is a power cell system that requires some degree of maintenance. Certain modes and activities have different amounts of drain to consider. And a recalled pokemon is in a somewhat dreamlike state, but that affects mostly the perception of time, and doesn't prohibit willful action or recognizing the outside world by sound, vibration, or in some cases other pokemon-specific senses. The longer a pokemon is in, however, the more vague and tranquilized the mental state becomes. And being reconstituted after a long period inside leads to significant disorientation both due to the time effect and the pokemon's mind and body being reformed in the state of recollection despite consciousness having proceeded, causing a moment of having two thoughts—then and now—at the same time.

>>53121913
>Why do Pokemon obey humans, and not create civilizations of their own?
Hardly canon but I always considered the mystery dungeon series an answer to a human-less pokemon world.

It comes down to pokemon just naturally attaching themselves to strong leaders. Weaker pokemon would group together to form fairly low tech civilizations with the stronger pokemon acting as leaders or protectors of group.

This tends to either be a low tech village like pokemon square protected by a pokemon guild or something more tribal/pack-like where a strong pokemon has control over a large territory like a desert or a mountain range.
Either way they rely on those stronger than them so they are more able to concentrate with their day to day needs. Any complex social structures arise out of necessity not ambition or greed.

Which is why Pokemon are naturally driven to humans as we are creatures of ambition and desire. The pokemon-trainer bond comes naturally from their desire to follow a strong leader.

Arceus is an extra-dimensional being from the same realm as Eternatus and Deoxys (and only those two, even Ultra Space is an offshoot of Mew).

It created Mew as a genetic progenitor to "pokeform" Earth, and its weird offspring were highly-mutable and super-adaptable creatures (hence evolution) that served as a single invasive species that took over the planet. It's why most of them can interbreed. One by one, Pokemon took over ecological niches on the planet by replacing and outperforming everything they encountered. Even fossil Pokemon are the result of Pokemon trying to copy fossils. Finally, it met its match with humanity. Despite trying to make exaggerated caricatures of different types of humans or myths and "gods" that people imagined, the Pokemon were not able to fully wrest humanity's control over the planet.

Arceus saw humanity's value when the ancient champion referred to in lore somehow saved the something or other, and grew to feel guilty over seeding Earth with its all-consuming offspring. It decided to oversee the symbiotic relationship formed by the two distinct lines of Pokemon and humanity. Mew, for its part, had long learned to control its own fissionable nature and stopped creating new organisms. And yes, Dittos are failed attempts at cloning Mew. It wasn't until human DNA was added as a stabilizer that Mewtwo was created.

Scrolling used to actually work when selecting a card from your deck with something like quickball. Now you have to fucking click and drag or click the fuckin arrow button one thousand times.

MY FUCKING BLACK AND WHITE HEXAGONS CARD SLEEVES ARE GONE WHAT THE FUCK

It really makes you think.
PLA should be the base moving forward.
Make buffs and statuses work like normal. (Maybe bring Drowsy in and change some sleep moves, and definitely bring in Frostbite and change almost all Freeze ice moves to that.)
But the best change to bring over is the change to the battle system. Speed is no longer the god stat and just determines how fast you can go. Agile-Strong patches up so many weak coverage moves (like the elemental bites) into ones that are pretty decent (60BP to 90BP).
And most everyone would prefer the ability to catch without battling mons that are "peaceful" to "timid". It just makes them feel more real when only the asshole mons force a battle on you. (By that same token, nerf catch XP.)

>but why 6 months? is there a specific timeframe or what?
there's a reason /vp/ixelmon starts sometime in spring and ends in august/september
having the server up for a limited amount of months forces players to actually value their time on the server instead of just mindlessly wandering the map/hiding in a corner like a hermit
it instead motivates people to leave a mark on the server, take the opportunity to interact with their fellow players, and do stuff while they still can
however the server will stay up for long enough each generation for there to be more than enough time to accomplish everything you plan on doing (making cool builds, getting all the badges to asset dominance over plebs, catching 'em all even though rule 5 is never enforced, etc) before everyone gets burnt out, assuming the server isn't terribly managed like last gen

>and do we get to suggest other mods?
assuming the host isn't a faggot like 2022 /vp/ixelmon
then probably yes

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53126967
Keep your distance, don't engage unless you have back-up, don't group up with your team during fights so you can't get multiple of you, and just wait for him to become out of position himself. Mamo only has one "gap closer" move and it has a long enough cooldown. It's not the best dash to actually keep up with other dashers. If you're able to just kite him, he'll either get annoyed and leave the fight (don't chase), or try to charge at you. Keep luring him back towards your team if he charges at you like a bull. He'll either KEEP doing it because he's getting cocky that he can take you, tilted that you're kiting him, or both or he'll eventually run away.

If he overextends and your team is nearby, you can just CC him and kill him. Don't try to take him on 1v1 as most meleemons, it'll either be a losing fight or a bit waste of your Ult.

Flame Charge Delphox, Flame Charge Cinderace, Mew, Glaceon, Gardevoir can kite him very well. Save your dashes or stuns for his inevitable Icicle Crash, he'll try to charge, hopefully miss you, turn around and run, then you use your max basic attack range to chip him down and annoy the fuck out of him until he re-engages.

>>53127247
Against most Defenders, most meleemons will struggle with a 1v1. It'll either be a waste of your time, a risk because you don't know how long the guy is stalling for his teammates to show up, or a waste of your resources (items or ult).

Like, yeah, you can sit there an wail on Slowbro as a Scizor for a full minute, but there's not really a lot of progress to be made there and his Espeon could show up and make it 2v1 where you're hard CC'd and lose. Now, if the Slowbro or Mamo are on YOUR side of the map trying to go for a backcap and you stop them, you can totally wail on them and ping for your team to help you take it down.

It's not even that a Defender is some hard-counter to meleemons, which are usually All-Arounders. It's just not a 1v1 worth taking. Do you really want to chase the Greedent as a Machamp? Do you really want to beat on a Blastoise as a Buzzwole when he's going to push you around and keep chipping your HP? Do you really want to go back-and-forth chipping a Mamo while he stuns you, chip and then get stunned, chip and then get stunned?

>Ranked is a joke. You shouldn't be able to climb to Masters in two fucking days

>First 8 minutes don't matter because of Rayquaza, he's too much of a comeback mechanic. Ray on release was ten times better.
>Game still gives you tutorials on fucking Remoat. Alongside the bot games, it goes out of its way to teach new players incorrect.

Unite has some of the worst MOBA players I've ever seen. There are people with 6,000 games who still make basic mistakes like backcapping during the Fug fight. No, it's not because "they're children". A child might play the game, but they are not grinding their way to 1600 Masters. A kid is going to hit a certain point in the game where they just keep getting destroyed by better players in Veterans or Ultra and they'll put the game down. Children don't normally play games that repeatedly make them frustrated the same way an adult would.

A lot of this shit is fixable. Making Ranked harder to climb would be a good start. How about just a normal ELO system like every other game? The same way Masters functions, but for every level.
0 - 500 = Beginner.
500 - 1500 = Great
1500 - 3000 = Veteran
3000 = 4000 = Ultra
6000+ = Masters

Maybe this way, I won't have Marco with a 47% WR who brute forced his way into Masters being paired up with me while the enemy team has fucking CrisHeroes and ToonSlim.

I'm not sure. This season I started in ultra 3 so I was in masters fairly quickly. Other sessions is taken me hundreds of matches. Sometimes I've made it in less than 50 matches. I guess it depends. As far as tips there aren't any specific tips I can give you as I do not know you or know what mistakes you are making. I'd need to see or play with or against you. I guess one general tip I can give is to update your emblems and use the most optimal builds and items. You should also be using the most optimal character for a situation and trying to fill roles. ideally you want to go jungle or attacker as often as possible but if your team has 4 attackers then maybe it's time to fill as a defender and if you have to play defender why not use the objectively best one which is Mamo and if you're going to use Mamo as the only defender why not use an emblem set that gives 400+ hp? Why not use the objectively best item for mamo which is rapid scarf that will allow you to stunlock anything that dares comes within your melee range?

Well that's my thoughts on it at least. Good luck.

I don’t think any new game will ever recapture the pixelated magic of the first two’s sprites or the crunchiness of those sound effects, and I haven’t genuinely enjoyed the series on any level other than “haha, I guess that’s a bit nice” for over a decade lol. I can’t tell if Pokémon is cursed to always look subpar in 3D or if it’s a symptom of PMD’s lower budgets, but I’ve just never liked the look of the games from GTI onwards, so I think even if a new game out I at least wouldn’t be satisfied.

As for everyone else- meh they’re probably fine, they’re not pretentious pixel-loving faggots like I am lol
I think a new game is unlikely, but will please many and prompt people to start heralding “the beginning of a Renaissance” no matter the quality just due to how damn long it’s been and how low the fanbase’s standards already are. A remake will be well-received but really declare it truly “over”.

Totodile went from genuine excitement for them both to go exploring to becoming mostly self-absorbed and using his partner as a tool. Partner eventually gets sick of this shit and snaps when they finally get a little bit of recognition and the Totodile takes all the credit, and leaves. Lots of time passes and the Totodile comes to regret what happened, eventually setting out on a new journey with new friends to prove he’s changed and apologize to the Beldum. Eventually kind of just gets BTFO as the Beldum has grown so spiteful that it purposely sought out similarly-abusive assholes to learn how to manipulate them back and achieve the pair’s dream on his own. Basically a different person by the time the Totodile finds him, partially because he’s already a Metagross chasing after an Awakening Emera, and the theoretical final battle is an extremely angsty “power of friendship” thing where the Totodile is simultaneously grieving the old friend he personally destroyed so long ago while assuring himself that he’s changed through beating said friend back with his new friends, whom he has much healthier relationships with

Damn Anon, that idea is really great. I will cry like a lil bitch if that becomes a real game all over again.

For my idea, I'm actually embarrassed to tell what it is so I just keep it all to myself for years but since it's all anonymous I guess this is fine, at least for once.
>Partner is your partner in the Human world when the hero was a trainer but neither of them know about that since the hero had amnesia and became a Pokemon. Not sure if Partner should lose memory here as well since they're already a Pokemon so there's no need to transform thus no amnesia, I guess. Partner's goal is to find their trainer and go back to the Human World with them. It took a while for them to find the hero and at the point, the partner joined a team and didn't recognize the hero despite being the one he was looking for, asked the hero to join them for the greater cause for his team and for his selfish desires. Along the way, he learnt about the Pokemon in this world and started to have second thoughts on the Human world and what should he do. In truth, he just wants his beloved friend back. Used this as a metaphor for the concept of Reincarnation in a way where the partner has to choose who does he choose at the end, as the hero is quite different compared to their Human counterpart thanks to the amnesia.
>Villain is a corrupt member of the "Agent of Spirits/Voices of Life", they brought the Hero in the Pokemon world despite the world is not in danger, unlike the previous times. They accidentally brought their Partner as well and they reached the world at different locations.
They did this because they have grown sick at being a pawn and wanted to be something else, even greater where they can do whatever they want and the Hero is the key to break their shackles. Like, they are going to trick the Hero to swap places where this agent/voice becomes the hero and the hero will become an agent/voice.

>What is it?
https://www.pokeclicker.com/
Pokéclicker is an open-source game built around the story and content of the Pokémon games. This is an idle & clicker type game that is currently in beta release phase. New content and patches are released frequently.

>Crobat?
https://crobat4.github.io/pokeclicker/
A modified version of Pokeclicker that features QoL changes from the original, including a Dock shortcut, type-based pokeball selection, Gen 3+ berries being available in dungeons, un-nerfed experience gains, and some egg-exclusive pokemon being available through other means.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53132819
grading 1st edition holos is probably worthwhile.

as a rule of thumb, don't expect anything to grade higher than a PSA 8, and probably don't grade anything worth less than $50 raw. (since grading costs at least $20/card anyway)

if you have a bunch of 9s/10s come back, then maybe the lower value cards are worth grading as well

the shadowless pikachus are probably best sold individually on tcgplayer or ebay. just load up on envelopes and toploaders and it's not too bad - get a label printer if you really want to speed things along

your blastoise looks good to me, not sure what the other anon is seeing

I started playing in gen 1 in tge early years of elementary school. Generation 4 came out when I was in High School, and I was absolutely delighted to see that there were about 20 or 30 kids at school in the auditorium playing this game when it came out, as I figured beforehand if I were to play it, I'd be the only one or made fun of. At the end of that very day I used up my money to grab Pearl and a DS. I loved that game and that time of my life. That was (in essense) the last purely happy period of my time, as the summer after that school year was when I started smoking weed, selling weed, fucking girls, I quit hockey, got caught up in a gang, dropped out of school in grade 12, had a dozen or so stints in jail/prison, etc.
It all worked out in the end, but I was fucked up until like 25 years old. Now I just work, ride motorcycles and play video games.

Gen 4 is definitely my favourite.

I think the main reason is that it had a headstart. I believe that gave it a major advantage on top of the pokedex description. But in general there's a few things that people find attractive in Pokémon design.

If we look at a wider picture we can see some of that in the data we have avaliable. Here for example is three different polls, the 4chan post is the smash percent ranked by number and the others is rule34.xxx and Tiermaker. The numbers on the right represent NSFW growth in the span of four months so you can divide that by 4 to get a rough NSFW per month number.

If we look at data there's Pokémon that are consistent in high placements AND also in getting a good number of NSFW art. Gardevoir, Lopunny, the eeveelutions with emphasis on Umbreon, Vaporeon and Sylveon, Braixen and to a lesser extend Delphox, and Zoroark.

Most of these are feminine designs and/or had a feminine portrayal like Zoroark in it's movie, which likely helped it a lot in this context, most are also cute. So cute and feminine designs seem to be what people like in Pokémon character design. Of course other factors like portrayal and popularity help, as in the case of Gardevoir and Lucario and to a lesser extent Zoroark, in the main series and also being seen as a legacy character like Lopunny. I also think the eeveelutions show that bodyshape isn't as big of a factor due to how ubiquitous they are in this context and even more so when you factor in how they're becoming more integrated into the mainstream perception of pokephilia.

They're both Pokémon which is, as far as I can tell, enough for most people. I will state as I've done many times that one can't ignore the context Pokémon find themselves in, in the series there's no distinction made between Pokémon for the most part. The series is far more concerned with the way they're portrayed and the series makers want a uniformed portrayal of them hence why the guidelines from the 2012 guide and what we know of the Detective Pikachu filmmakers working with The Pokémon Company.

Because of this, in my opinion, Pokémon attraction has a pretty unique context which extends to the way people perceive Pokémon and the way these results manifest themselves.

It's why I like using that "horsemen of the apocalypse" tweet with Vaporeon, Gardevoir, Lucario and Lopunny because it shows there is a consciousness on which Pokémon are sexualized and which exist in the forefront of Pokephilia. I think far more telling is how widespread the Vaporeon copypasta is, in public nsfw subreddits people constantly post it in Pokémon post that get traction including Gardevoir, and they also like the tiktok meme with Batman and Joker. YouTube channels like Sum and Pokemon Drunk Oak cycle through the same Pokémon and that includes the eeveelutions especially in the case of Sum. These are channels with a wide audience for what they create. The latest viralish video, furrymon, had a rapping vaporeon on the cover.

Eeveelution attraction has always been present, Sylveon, Glaceon and Umbreon attest to that, but the vaporeon pasta gave it a face to rally around. It's become so entrenched that Vaporeon can challenge established Pokémon in general spaces like Vaporeon taking the spot of the most upvoted picture from Gardevoir in rule34.

This is also acknowledged by the anime staff.
https://youtu.be/DuItIoZKghw
The choice of Glaceon is very deliberate, it may not be Vaporeon but it predates the blow up of the meme, they could have put Tsareena but didn't.

That's the kind of thing you would keep to yourself. Nevertheless people might think the same of Pokémon attraction in general. There's still a stigma against Pokémon attraction and there's still people who equate all Pokémon attraction with (fictional) bestiality. Which is why Pokémon has a rather unique situation where it appears people don't care about the shape of Pokémon as much as one would think. It's been mentioned how widespread the vaporeon meme is, Ludwig Aghren who was the most subscribed Twitch streamer and has connections to MrBeast had a video on YouTube where he talks about wet Vaporeon pussy to his audience of millions. Most telling is Ninetales results in PokeSmash, remember Ninetales has no modern memes to help it out. posts.com:
Time for my threadly plug for the VN I'm writing. Hang out with Cynthia in Olivine City and solve crimes! Also featuring Jasmine. It's completely free.

writefuck.itch.io/olivinelights

>What's new?

Mostly finished writing a sidequest with Jasmine. It took a little while due to some writers' block, but it's in a good place. I've implemented some achievements (picrel) which primarily are there so the player/reader knows what content has and hasn't been seen yet. Achievements will be persistent between playthroughs and some of them also unlock things in an "extras" menu that will include things like showing your cynthia_love and jasmine_love stats, or starting off with your pokemon evolved. This will probably all be available in the next major update, but...

I'm having a hard time commissioning actual art for this for some reason. I need several SFW CG's and a whole bunch of NSFW ones, and I have plenty of money to throw at some artists, but out of everyone I PM'd or DM'd, almost no one has even answered me. Maybe I'm just being impatient, I dunno. I need a better way to recruit artists than just cold calling randos. I wish I had artist friends.

I'm getting increasingly uncomfortable with the fact that the VN contains art that's completely stolen from pixiv or deviantart and used without permission. My priority for commissioning CG's is to replace all the stolen art with paid art that I have permission to use. I might open up a ko-fi or something after I've done that. I won't put this behind a paywall, but I won't decline donations once I'm not using stolen art anymore. I'm not worried about official art or sprites stolen from Nintendo since I'm using their IP anyway, and I'm pretty sure I'm covered under fair use doctrine regardless. I just don't feel right stealing art from random strangers even though I'm not making money off of it. I might hold off on releasing another update until I have new art to replace the stolen assets. Not sure.

inb4 "just use AI"

>>53128720
Because it's a metaphor. In a literary sense, stones not working on Eevee means that an evolition can't be forced, just like you can't force yourself to grow up. It's about cherishing your childhood, being true to yourself, and not succumbing to other people's expectations. Chloe learned to admit to herself that pokemon are something she is interested in by her own merit and not because of her dad. And in a metanarrative sense it acts as an open ended conclusion of a perpetual journey for our heroes.

>>53131985
There's a few different answers
Some have a fetishized idea of "wifing" a tomboy, she becomes more of a girl through her bond with a man.
Alternatively some people like that they don't have to be considerate about certain stereotypical girl concerns because she's "one of the guys". Which invites comfort for the men around her.

For storytelling reasons the tomboy changes the romance dynamic to be a little more ambiguous, if she likes you she won't operate the same way other girls do.
In traditional media, characters who could be called tomboys raise the stakes of what it takes to be a "man".
In modern media, a tomboy also stands as inspiration that women are not forced to be a certain way. This in particular was big in 1990s childrens movies.

A girl might swoon and fall in love, a tomboy has to *fall* in love with you.

Honestly I think by now due to power creep all starters (and mascots like Lucario and Zoroark) need a bst boost.
Parity with pseudos at 600 bst would be best.
Maybe throw in a change in abilities too.
Only rule is no single stat above 125.

Example:
>Sceptile
>Unburden becomes Sharpness
>bst 530 becomes bst 600
>70->90 Hp
>85->115 Atk
>65->85 Def
>Expand move pool with most blade moves including Sacred sword

>Thyplosion
>Flash fire becomes Drought
>534 bst to 600
>78->90 Hp
>85->109 Atk
>78->90 Def
>109->119 SpA
>85->90 SpD
>100->102
>Bulk up and calm mind as booster moves
>Gets Aura sphere, Energy ball, Earth power, Shadow ball and Extrasensory as special coverage

From the above you can see that the starters are lackluster in modern gameplay.

As for Lucario and Zoroark I'd actually give them some bulk or speed instead of messing with any of their offensive stats.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53107642
Outbreaks work on a per day basis and only on the outbreak itself.
So for example if you're doing a Flittle outbreak and you kill 60, it will boost the shiny odds for the flittle that spawn FROM the outbreak, not from the wild spawns.

Once the day rolls over, it will do new outbreaks, the game tries to give you an outbreak close to you and this is how you try to do specific outbreaks.

So your Flittle outbreak is gone and you'd have to do the battles again.
HOWEVER, you can just use the lets go auto battle thing, it can never kill a shiny and it will count on each kill, making it go by extremely fast

posts.com:
>>53112798
You're meant to kill 60, then save, close your game, fiddle with the clock until you get dusk/few minutes before THEN re-save and sandwich. If you don't get the dusk, restart, reset the clock to the time you'd just used to run the first hunt, then re-hunt, continually resetting the clock to allow Dusk spawns to happen.
You're right, trying this without thinking WILL be a pain in the arse. But that's why you think about it first.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53106289
Picnic reset is only for a very small number of areas, particularly near cliffs or water.
Otherwise, you're better off moving around - it spawns new pokemon faster and despawns the old ones faster than setting up and packing a picnic.
Plus, it's less tedious and you have more control - you can allow a cluster of the pokemon to build up in an area while you clear one side, check them all at once, then clear them while checking the other, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53128957
Marowak and Exeggutor are regional forms, as they have the same name as the original.
Obstagoon and Purrzerker are regional evolutions, as they evolve from a Pokemon in a regional forms.
Bellossom, Magmortar and Dudunsparce are cross-gen evolutions, new pokemon that evolve from old Pokemon without the old Pokemon receiving a new form.

Ursaluna fits the bottom category the most, as it does not evolve from a regional variant of an existing Pokemon, it just evolves from that Pokemon.

Yes this does mean Basculegion and Sneasler are regional evolutions, but the other hisui evos are not. I didn't make the rules.

That said, you’re living under a rock if you think the series doesn’t have some major balancing issues. Not even necessarily referring to the terrible level balance btw, one of the major issues that I think contributes to a lack of difficulty is an over abundance of resources. Granted, what counts as “too many” items really depends, but as it is the game gives you countless healing items and TMs when you truthfully don’t really NEED any of it at all, because the game is already so easy without it. And at that point it’s like, what’s the point? Why pretend like resources are limited when they’re effectively bottomless? That’s just ONE of the ways modern Pokémon completely fumbles what could otherwise add even the slightest bit of mechanical depth to the series too.

Tldr the series doesn’t need to be “hardcore” but it really needs to start actually presenting the player with stuff to work around.
